thread.title: 'Too late to leave' some areas as bushfire emergency grips NSW
thread.title_full: 'Too late to leave' some areas as bushfire emergency grips NSW

title: 'Too late to leave' some areas as bushfire emergency grips NSW
text:
Properties are under threat as fires rage across New South Wales amid soaring temperatures and catastrophic conditions. Key points: An emergency warning has been issued for a blaze at Leadville, near Dunedoo There are reports of damage to several properties Much of NSW is experiencing "catastrophic" fire conditions and soaring temperatures 
The NSW Rural Fire Service (NSW RFS) has issued emergency warnings for two separate blazes. 
At Leadville, near Dunedoo, a fire breached containment lines and is heading east, while another fire at Beechwood, 50 kilometres west of Port Macquarie is threatening properties. 
People affected by the fire at Leadville have been told to evacuate, while those at Lower Pappinbarra are being warned to seek shelter. 
The 2,000-hectare fire burning since yesterday at Leadville near Dunedoo, east of Dubbo, is moving at 12 kilometres per hour and has burned some property, RFS Deputy Commissioner Rob Rogers said. Video: NSW RFS deputy commissioner Rob Rogers updates on the Sir Ivan fire. (ABC News) 
The RFS is saying it is now too late for some residents to leave the path of the Leadville fire: 
"People in the area of Uarby, Turill and Cassilis should seek shelter as the fire front approaches. It is too late to leave," it said. 
"People to the east of Cassilis should leave now towards Merriwa if the path is clear. People to the north of Ulan should move south towards Mudgee if the path is clear." External Link: Fire Emergency Warning 
Meanwhile, several isolated rural properties are also under threat at Beechwood. 
Two fires are burning to the west of Wauchope in the vicinity of Pappinbarra Rd moving in an South Easterly direction towards Beechwood. 
The fire is spreading quickly under worsening conditions. 
Residents in the vicinity of Pappinbarra Rd in Hollisdale, Lower Pappinbarra and Beechwood are advised to seek shelter as the fire front arrives. 
More than 1,000 RFS firefighters are battling 76 fires across the state, with 26 of those not yet contained. 
Eight fires on the state's mid north coast and in the central west are under watch and act alert levels at O'Connell, Narromine, Goolma, Myall River, Terreel, Wherrol Flat and Giro.
